author: @Stanislav-Tomov
text: Guys, I think most people don't realize that in 2014 Russia didn't move troops to Crimea. This would actually be pretty difficult and dangerous since Crimea didn't have any land connection to mainland Russia. Russian troops had been in Crimea since forever, in the Russian naval base of Sevastopol. Faced with a hostile pro-NATO puppet government in Kiev, the Crimean knot (95% Russian population + main Russian naval base on Black sea + Crimean autonomy inside Ukraine) resolved almost by itself.

author: @skylangford6083
text: Love your take on the video however I do need to correct you on one thing. There is no physical evidence of DPRK combat troops present in the Kursk region. I do accept that there might be troops training in Russia and I do accept that there could be combat engineers from the DPRK that were sent to the Kursk region to gain some understanding of the conflict however even the latter would prove extremely difficult due to integration and language. Brian Berletic at The New Atlas and Mark Sleboda have discussed this subject quite thoroughly and have explained the difficulties in North Korean integration within another nations military such as Russia
